s1.title: Calling XFC from the command line
s1.p: The XFC distribution includes a script called runconverter.sh/bat which can be used to invoke XFC from the command line. It accepts two parameters naming the input and output modules, eg:

All supported options can be listed by supplying --help as a parameter:
$> ./runconverter --help XFC - The Avalon Excalibur (X)Conf (F)ile (C)onverter Usage: java org.apache.excalibur.xfc.Main [options]
Options: -h, --help print this message and exit -v, --version print this version and exit -i, --input <argument> set the input module name and context -o, --output <argument> set the output module name and context -d, --debug enable debug logging
Example: java org.apache.excalibur.xfc.Main\ --input ecm:conf/ecm.roles:conf/ecm.xconf \ --output fortress:conf/fortress.roles:conf/fortress.xconf

s1.title: Calling XFC from an ANT task
s1.p: The XFC distribution includes an ANT task (defined in the org.apache.excalibur.xfc.ant.XFCTask class).
To use the ANT task, include the following custom task definition in your build.xml:
s1.source: <!-- Test XFC Ant task --> <taskdef name="xfc" classname="org.apache.excalibur.xfc.ant.XFCTask"> <classpath refid="your.projects.class.path"/> </taskdef>
s1.p: and then call XFC as a normal ANT task defining your input and output module types and contexts:

s1.title: Calling XFC from Java
s1.p: It's also possible to invoke XFC from within Java. To do this call the method org.apache.excalibur.xfc.Main.main, and pass as an array of String objects the same parameters you would normally give on the command line.
